Any creature in the line must spend 2 feet of movement for every 1 foot it moves when moving further away from you.

The wind disperses gas or vapor, and it extinguishes candles, torches, campfires, and similar unprotected flames in the area. It causes protected flames, such as those of lanterns, to dance wildly, and has a 50-percent chance to extinguish them.
As a bonus action on each of your turns, you can change the point from which the line originates.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the line grows wider by 5 feet and deals an additional {@damage 2d4} cold damage for each slot level above 3rd.

monsterFluff.name: Acrasian Alpha
entries: Mightiest and cleverest of acrasians, acrasian alphas lead packs no smaller than ten and no larger than two dozen. Though advised by other wise members of their packs, they are the undisputed masters; the oldest, strongest, and largest members of the pack.

The rare battles for dominance between two mature acrasians vying for power are terrible indeed. Both massive goblinoids tear at one anothers' hides with claws and teeth until one falls and the other stands victorious.

Acrasian alphas command the first choice of bounty after a hunt and lead the charge into battle against frost giants and yeti. While the largest and most powerful members of the pack, they are far from brutes. Alphas possess the tactical cunning necessary to maximize their forces' efficiency, identify weaknesses in enemy defenses, and target key commanders among their foes.

entries.name: Acrasians
entries: Though superficially similar to yeti, acrasians are a species of robust, hulking goblinoids that lurk in arboreal forests and glacial valleys. Clad in heavy owlbear hides and bearing bloody claws, these pack hunters migrate south in winter to supplement their diets of moose and caribou by stalking smaller humanoid prey.
Preferring to target small caravans, and isolated homesteads, acrasians take perverse pleasure in the terror their looming presence invokes.

Their versatility as hunters of men and beasts is unmatched: they can vanish into driving snow in the blink of an eye, scale slick ice cliffs, and wade through piled snow like water. While large and powerful in stature, they are not slow; instead, acrasians can cross vast distances of ice and snow with ease, and few obstacles slow them.
Worse still, acrasians possess the fierce intelligence to exploit the speed and strength nature granted them and fully enjoy their status as creatures of terror across northern folklore.

entries.name: Masked Carvers
entries: Acrasians craft terrifying masks of wood and bone to conceal their faces and supplement their mystique. Parents design masks for young acrasians modeled after their own. The process of designing and carving one's own mask marks an acrasian's passage into adulthood.

In addition to wood and bone, acrasians accentuate their masks with trophies taken from kills: owlbear claws, frost giant armor, and even the teeth of white dragons, whose boorish intelligence and reliance on their freezing breath makes them little match for a coordinated acrasian pack.

Acrasians enjoy carving as a stimulating artistic activity, as well. When not hunting humans for sport, they carve bone and wood into intricate totems, ornamentation, and gifts for one another. While some employ knives taken from their victims, most use their claws to whittle grooves into their pieces. These artistic objects form the bulk of any loot or treasure hoard taken from the dens they carve out of glacial walls and mountain caves.

entries.name: Territorial Hunters
entries: In addition to humanoids, the fiercely territorial acrasians clash with yeti and ice giants when their borders overlap.

Acrasians advertise their territorial borders with runic claw markings placed above the forest snowdrifts. The ignorant mistake the markings for bear scratchings, but the geometric shapes indicate to most that they have crossed into hostile territory. Acrasians carve or paint these symbols on their masks, which makes their loyalties identifiable at a glance.

In these battles for prey and territory, acrasians apply their mental acuity to tactical combat, setting traps and flanking their enemies with advanced ambush tactics and guerilla warfare. This advanced warfare serves two purposes: defense of territory, and entertainment. Acrasians attack more well-armed and fortified humans and giants for the welcome challenge and chance to test their abilities, since their natural talents make hunts for wildlife like moose and owlbears effortless, boring, and unfulfilling.

These hunts are for sport as much as food. Some northern legends tell of a village that escaped an acrasian attack by hosting a festival of art and cooked meat, which pleased the pack and headed off the hunt. No attempts at successfully replicating this appeasement have been recorded, but many northern villages still leave offerings of smoked meat, furs, and carvings at the outskirts of their villages after the first snowfall.

entries.name: Pack Loyalists
entries: Acrasians form groups of multiple mated pairs, their children, and extended family, ruled by the pack alpha. These packs control an expansive hunting grounds of glacial mountain forests and snowy foothills, and expand in search of additional food or sport.

Though acrasian packs often clash, the interplay of attraction and competition ensures a healthy flow of fresh individuals between packs. In most cases, a young female joins the pack of her male mate, and integrates the symbol of his pack into her mask alongside the emblem of her birth family.
Both male and female acrasians hunt, as do their adolescent offspring. Hunting groups bring acrasians of varied ages and skills together, and make the most of their individual talents.
Acrasian witches join only the most significant hunts. They spend most of their time at home, where they raise children too immature to act as scouts and ambushers.

This supervision provides another motivation for acrasians to carve totems and figures. The acrasian witches, wounded, and elderly entertain the children with re-enactments of past hunts. They use figurines and props carved in shocking detail to emphasize their tales, and reshape the snow around them to replicate the terrain of past hunts in miniature.

monsterFluff.name: Acrasian Ambusher
entries: The smallest and youngest members of an acrasian pack, acrasian ambushers rarely fight directly.  Instead, the older and more experienced  hunters use them as scouts and spies. This teaches the young acrasians how to chooes and track their prey, and how to monitor them for weaknesses.
Acrasian ambushers lie in wait for prey, buried in the snowdrifts outside heavily forested areas. There, they ambush prey fleeing from their parents and mentors who think themselves safe.
Ambushers strike hard and fast with claws not yet dulled by years of hunting, then vanish into the snow as the rest of the pack claims the kill.

monsterFluff.name: Acrasian Hunter
entries: These more typical adult acrasians form the majority of the pack's population. While a single acrasian hunter is a dangerous foe capable of tearing through an isolated northern village with ease, hunters rarely travel in groups smaller than four and prefer to form hunting groups as large as seven or eight.
Studded with trophies from their greatest hunts and proud to recognize one anothers' feats of combat and psychological manipulation, acrasian hunters form the core of any pack.

Outside hunts, acrasian hunters mate for life and are fiercely devoted to their partner and children. Mates modify their masks to match elements of their partner's mask, and court each other with gifts of trophies and feats of good-natured competition and flirtatious physical dominance.

Wrestling between mates and against competition is a common social activity among acrasian adults, encouraging physical fitness and providing relief from tension over lean winters without exciting prey.

monsterFluff.name: Acrasian Witch
entries: Advisors and often mates to an alpha, these acrasians represent the pack's peak in mental acuity and magical ability. They put this intelligence to great use in hunts and learn the language of their favorite prey to better understand them, intimidate them, and deliver ultimatums. Typical choices include the languages of humans, dragons, giants, fey, or giant animals.

While they paralyze targets with frigid ice and freeze the ground beneath their feet, witches are not limited to stopping mundane prey. They love to terrify spellcasters with well-placed fog clouds and fields of silence to limit the unfortunate mage's options in a duel between spellcasters.

Either advanced in age or laden with fetishes and totems, acrasian witches move much slower than their hunter brethren. They compensate with the ability to step from one tree to another at will, which allows them to easily keep pace with the pack in the arboreal forest hunting grounds they favor.

Anecdotes of travelers trading with hunched, shambling individuals bearing intricate masks and elaborate beadwork in the woods during the dead of winter seem to indicate that the witches might be the most open to friendly interaction with other creatures. This does not, however, mean that they can be trusted. And as some of the most intelligent and valued members of a pack, acrasian witches are known to never travel alone...

If an acrasian witch finds herself without her pack—fallen to starvation, disease, or warfare, or lost in the wilderness—she seeks out other wintery spellcasters like herself and forms a hag coven. They most commonly ally with bheur hags, who make their homes in similar northern climes.

entries.name: Acrasians
entries: Though superficially similar to yeti, acrasians are a species of robust, hulking goblinoids that lurk in arboreal forests and glacial valleys. Clad in heavy owlbear hides and bearing bloody claws, these pack hunters migrate south in winter to supplement their diets of moose and caribou by stalking smaller humanoid prey.
Preferring to target small caravans, and isolated homesteads, acrasians take perverse pleasure in the terror their looming presence invokes.

Their versatility as hunters of men and beasts is unmatched: they can vanish into driving snow in the blink of an eye, scale slick ice cliffs, and wade through piled snow like water. While large and powerful in stature, they are not slow; instead, acrasians can cross vast distances of ice and snow with ease, and few obstacles slow them.
Worse still, acrasians possess the fierce intelligence to exploit the speed and strength nature granted them and fully enjoy their status as creatures of terror across northern folklore.

entries.name: Masked Carvers
entries: Acrasians craft terrifying masks of wood and bone to conceal their faces and supplement their mystique. Parents design masks for young acrasians modeled after their own. The process of designing and carving one's own mask marks an acrasian's passage into adulthood.

In addition to wood and bone, acrasians accentuate their masks with trophies taken from kills: owlbear claws, frost giant armor, and even the teeth of white dragons, whose boorish intelligence and reliance on their freezing breath makes them little match for a coordinated acrasian pack.

Acrasians enjoy carving as a stimulating artistic activity, as well. When not hunting humans for sport, they carve bone and wood into intricate totems, ornamentation, and gifts for one another. While some employ knives taken from their victims, most use their claws to whittle grooves into their pieces. These artistic objects form the bulk of any loot or treasure hoard taken from the dens they carve out of glacial walls and mountain caves.

entries.name: Territorial Hunters
entries: In addition to humanoids, the fiercely territorial acrasians clash with yeti and ice giants when their borders overlap.

Acrasians advertise their territorial borders with runic claw markings placed above the forest snowdrifts. The ignorant mistake the markings for bear scratchings, but the geometric shapes indicate to most that they have crossed into hostile territory. Acrasians carve or paint these symbols on their masks, which makes their loyalties identifiable at a glance.

In these battles for prey and territory, acrasians apply their mental acuity to tactical combat, setting traps and flanking their enemies with advanced ambush tactics and guerilla warfare. This advanced warfare serves two purposes: defense of territory, and entertainment. Acrasians attack more well-armed and fortified humans and giants for the welcome challenge and chance to test their abilities, since their natural talents make hunts for wildlife like moose and owlbears effortless, boring, and unfulfilling.

These hunts are for sport as much as food. Some northern legends tell of a village that escaped an acrasian attack by hosting a festival of art and cooked meat, which pleased the pack and headed off the hunt. No attempts at successfully replicating this appeasement have been recorded, but many northern villages still leave offerings of smoked meat, furs, and carvings at the outskirts of their villages after the first snowfall.

entries.name: Pack Loyalists
entries: Acrasians form groups of multiple mated pairs, their children, and extended family, ruled by the pack alpha. These packs control an expansive hunting grounds of glacial mountain forests and snowy foothills, and expand in search of additional food or sport.

Though acrasian packs often clash, the interplay of attraction and competition ensures a healthy flow of fresh individuals between packs. In most cases, a young female joins the pack of her male mate, and integrates the symbol of his pack into her mask alongside the emblem of her birth family.
Both male and female acrasians hunt, as do their adolescent offspring. Hunting groups bring acrasians of varied ages and skills together, and make the most of their individual talents.
Acrasian witches join only the most significant hunts. They spend most of their time at home, where they raise children too immature to act as scouts and ambushers.

This supervision provides another motivation for acrasians to carve totems and figures. The acrasian witches, wounded, and elderly entertain the children with re-enactments of past hunts. They use figurines and props carved in shocking detail to emphasize their tales, and reshape the snow around them to replicate the terrain of past hunts in miniature.

monsterFluff.name: Acrasian Zombie
entries: When an acrasian alpha or a challenger for its position dies, acrasian witches freeze its spilled blood into segmented icy armor and crude, glistening weapons around its claws. Then, they animate the corpse through an elaborate necromantic ritual.

Unlike most zombies, reanimated acrasians retain much of their sanity and will not attack other acrasians, though none of their predatory cunning remains. In acrasian zombies, relentless bloodlust replaces patient strategy.

Despite their lingering intelligence, acrasians treat these zombies as unliving weapons instead of members of the pack. They preserve the zombies in glaciers, permafrost, and snowbanks until they go to war against the few opponents capable of matching their skills.

An acrasian zombie's rare appearance is an ill omen for yeti camps and frost giant forts, for their presence is tantamount to a declaration of total war. They signal the acrasians' willingness to march as an elemental force—the personification of winter's cold hatred for all things living.
